metadata.title: An updated review on the influential parameters on thermal conductivity of nano-fluids

sections.text:
1
Nano-fluids are produced by combining one or more nano-particles in a base-fluid. Nano-fluids, especially hybrid nano-fluids, have better thermal conductivitys than simple liquids. The results of various articles demonstrated that various parameters such as nano-particles size, their volume fraction, temperature, aspect ratio, base-fluid, nano inclusions, additive, and pH affect nano-fluid thermal conductivity. In this paper, the effect of these parameters is reviewed by considering experimental works performed on thermal conductivity. Since thermal conductivity is measured by researchers experimentally, it is also important for researchers to understand the effect of nanoparticles on humans and the environment. Thus, in this article, published articles in this field are reviewed and the effect of nano-particles on human and environment are investigated. The results of these articles indicated that nano-particles can endanger human health and can have irreversible effects on human health. The nano-particles also have a devastating effect on the environment and can affect the water, soil, and animals.
Keywords: Nano-fluids; Thermal conductivity; Environment; Human Health; Effective Parameters; Hybrid Nano-fluids;

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The advances in nano-fluids-related technologies have attracted many scholars and researchers in recent years. This can be understood from the number of papers presented in the nano-fluids field each year (Fig 1.). Researchers have improved the state of the systems in many applications, including energy storage, HVAC, electronics and microfluidics, shipping, renewable energies and medicine [1-11].
4
One of the applications of nano-particles, which have been attracted by the researchers, is nano drug delivery [12-17]. One of the most important subjects considered by many researchers is the issue of heat transfer with nano-fluids [18-26]. Nano-fluids consist of nanoscale particles and basic fluid (e.g. water, ethylene glycol, oil, etc.) [11]. Nano-particles are the particles that are smaller than 100nm. The nano-particles themselves may include metals, metal oxides, nonmetallic oxides, etc., or a combination of them. One of the most important topics in the field of nanotechnology is its influence on the environment and human health. Due to the improvement of nanoscience in various industries in many parts of the world, nano-particles are produced in industrial workshops or laboratories today. This makes the number of people affected by the nano-particles in these locations or even around these regions [27- 31]. The environment can be also affected by these impacts. It is now important to evaluate how the nano-particles affect humans and their environment. The researchers have studied the effects of different nano-particles on the human body [32-36]. Increased use of engineered Nano-particles releases these substances into the environment and increases pollution, which is a threat to human
5
health [37]. The small size of Nano-particles and their activation affect the health of the environment and raise concerns about the safety of transport, the toxicity of these particles and the threat to human health [38, 39].
Most of the studies have so far concentrated on the evaluation of the thermo-physical properties of
nano-particles and using the effective changes in their properties. The basis of production of this type of fluid is using the thermal conductivity of suspended solids in the fluid. Thus, it is clear that most studies, since the production of the first nano-fluids have been about the changes in thermophysical properties, especially the thermal conductivity [40]. Many of these investigations were also about the properties of nano-fluids, such as viscosity [41-45], density [46-49], thermal conductivity [50-53], specific heat [54, 55], etc. [56-62]. Given the increasing need for energy and the decline in natural resources, researchers are trying to increase energy efficiency of heating devices. A way of increasing the thermal efficiency of these devices is increasing heat transfer. After years of research, researchers concluded that heat transfer can be improved using nano-fluids [63-72]. According to previous studies, heat transfer may increase using nano-fluids. The higher the nano-fluids thermal conductivity leads to the better heat transfer process. So far, many researchers have tried to measure the nano-fluids thermal conductivity in a variety of ways to provide a comprehensive relationship to measure this in nano-fluids. A great number of studies have been done about the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids over the years. Studies are also required to review these articles in order to determine how much progress has been made in this regard. Writing review articles helps other researchers find out what has been done so far to try to improve it. In recent years, hybrid nanofluids have received much attention and many researchers have investigated their properties. In hybrid nano-fluids, instead of using one nano-particles, two or more nano-particles are used. In many cases, hybrid nano-fluids have better properties than mono nano-fluids [73]. Now, according to the above-mentioned explanations, experimental studies on nano-fluids thermal conductivity are discussed in this paper. The influence of each parameter is examined separately includes their increasing or decreasing effect. Due to the importance of hybrid nano-fluids, a separate section related to the articles published in this field is provided. An important part of the work also explores the impact of nano-particles on humans and the environment.

sections.heading: 2. Classical research on the thermal conductivity
sections.text:
In 1881, Maxwell [74] proposed the first relationship to calculate the thermal conductivity. This relationship was presented for solid suspensions in liquid. This relationship is also still a widely used relationship for nano-fluids. Of course, this relationship is very accurate for spherical nano-
6
particles and low solid volume fractions of nano-particles. Maxwell's relation is based on the theory of effective environment and is as follows: (1) 345365 = 347 365 8347 3659:347 365 8347 3659: In which k0 is the fluid thermal conductivity, k; is the nano-particles thermal conductivity and k<0 is the nano-fluids thermal conductivity. Although this relationship only determines the conduction as a function of the nano-particles volume fraction and the thermal conductivity of the components, it is obvious that increasing the ratio of the surface to the volume of the particle should increase the thermal conductivity of the mixture. For example, for a particle with a diameter of less than 20 nm, about 20% of the atoms are placed at its surface, which makes it easier to transfer heat between the particle and the fluid; while Maxwell's relation is unable to investigate this effect. The three above-mentioned relations have a major disadvantage that they do not take into account the size or diameter of the particles. The value of the thermal conductivity obtained from the above models is lower than the experimental values and the error value increases with volume fraction increase. Most of the studies carried out to find the reasons for these differences indicate that there are mechanisms for transferring heat in the nano-fluids, which is not very important in large dimensions. Among those are Brownian's motion, clustering of particles by adherence, forming a thin layer of fluid around a nano-particles and enhancing its thermal conductivity. Wasp et al. sections.heading: 3. Effect of nano-particles on environment
sections.text:
The environment is one of the fundamental keys of sustainable development. In this regard, there must be an interrelationship between the basis of the sustainable development model, such as economic growth and technological growth, in a way that can reduce the shortcomings of the previous development models. This should be done so that the current development patterns become more stable and the development process leads to that the nature system does not lose its
8
equilibrium dynamics. In recent years, rapid developments in nanotechnology have led to major developments in the fields of environment, medicine, agriculture, industry and other sciences. Nano-particles technology has also played a major role in the field of nanotechnology. Nanoparticles have wide applications such as environmental, pharmaceutical, nutritional, clinical diagnostic and therapeutic applications, cosmetics, agriculture, energy, textile and electronics. Environmental applications of nano-particles can also be addressed, such as the removal of pollutants from water, sewage, and air. Other applications include environmental instruments such as sensors and green nanotechnology, for example, reduction of greenhouse gas [86-92]. Nanoparticles can be threat to the environment, humans and animals from production to disposal. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the environmental risks of nano-particles throughout the life cycle of nano-particles. Considering the widespread production of nanomaterials, there is a emergent need to study their potential toxic effects on the human body and the environment. The people who are working in nanotechnology and research centers are most exposed to the nanoparticles during their production, transportation, and final application. Nano-particles have attracted much attention in the medical and diagnostic sciences. A new medicine branch called nanomedicine has been created. Nano-particles are widely used in products because of their unique properties. However, there is enough evidence that they cause toxicity to humans and wildlife. Cellular absorption of these particles may produce cytotoxicity by producing reactive oxygen species. Cytotoxicity and genotoxicity of nano-particles have been studied by a number of researchers [93- 96]. Specific characteristics of nano-particles increase their application in domestic and industrial processes and consequently increase their toxicity. Toxicity of nano-particles depends on their properties such as size, shape, nature, surface chemistry, synthesis environment charge, storage time, accumulation, stability, displacement and their reactivity. Skin contact, respiratory, and gastrointestinal exposure are three main pathways for human and wildlife exposure to nanoparticles. Skin contact may be through conscious or unconscious methods. Nano-based cosmetics are used directly on the skin and are the most common way of knowing the nano-particles. Although the skin is an effective barrier against particle penetration, sweat glands and follicles provide a pathway for particle penetration. Breathing also provides a pathway to the lungs through which particles pass to different parts of the body. The issue of moving from lungs to other organs is controversial and challenging. Nano-particles in food products and drugs are directly eaten. They enter the gastrointestinal tract and interact with lymph cells [97–103]. Swallowed particles are repelled due to their nature, but they may die if the gastrointestinal tract is blocked by these particles. Environmental conditions are important in determining the toxicity of engineered nanoparticles. Exposure and contact with nano-particles can be controlled through control equipment and engineering tools in the workplace. Using personal protective equipment, checkups and regular
9
medical examinations may also reduce the risk of exposure to nano-particles. Studies on the toxicity of nano-particles have been widely dispersed and various toxicity assessments have been performed on different nano-particles. It is not possible to reach a definitive conclusion based on existing studies. Therefore, standard methods for recognizing the toxicity of different types of nano-particles should be developed [104-109].

sections.heading: 4. Hybrid and CNT nano-fluids
sections.text:
A nano-fluid that is made from more than one nano-particle is called a hybrid nano-fluids. The use of several properties of the material makes the hybrid nano-fluids, and the scientists have attained various results after reviewing these fluids. In any case, the hybrid nano-particles can be divided into 3 groups expressed in Ref. [110]. Turning to a high carbon heat capacity, its use is very high in nano-fluids heat transfer applications. Although, due to the limited use of studies, there is not much research, but recently, along with the development of manufacturing technology of carbon nanotubes, the number of studies in this section has augmented intensely. Since carbon was constructed as a nano-additive, because of its high thermal capacity and its possible for enhancing thermal conductivity, suspensions prepared by it were developed by the scientists. Among the identified nano-particles, nano-fluids prepared with carbon nanotubes have been very usually used by the large enhancement of the thermal conductivity. Although the number of studies implemented on this nano-particle is less common than other frequently used nano-particles, the investigations are very inclusive and contain inclusive information on this nano-fluids type.
Single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), graphite,
and graphene oxide are commonly used materials to make carbon nanocomposites. Assael et al. [111] studied the thermal conductivity of water containing 0.6, 0.75 and 1% of DWCNTs volume fractions at room temperature. They established that with growing solid volume fraction of nano-particles, the thermal conductivity also enhanced. Ding et al. [112] examined the thermal conductivity of MWCNTs/water in solid volume fraction range of 0.05-0.49% and temperatures ranging from 25 to 25°C and reported that thermal conductivity enhanced with growing temperature and volume fraction. Liu et al. [113] studied the thermal conductivity of MWCNTs in base-fluids of EG, EO and water by volume frictions of 1, 1.5 and 2% at room temperature. They found that by increasing the thermal conductivity of the base-fluid, the enhancement of thermal conductivity of nano-fluids decreases. Wang et al. [114] examined graphite / oil nanocrystals in a solid volume fraction age of 1.36 and room temperature. They obtained a nanoscale particle size and finally established that, by addition of nano-particles, the ratio of
10
thermal conductivity improved by 1.36% to the base-fluid. Sun et al. [115] added graphene nanoparticles to water-base and polymer poly, respectively, and tested at room temperature. They reported that adding graphene nano-particles to the base-fluid led to a noteworthy enhancement of thermal conductivity. Afrand [116] examined the thermal conductivity of the MgO-MWCNTs/EG hybrid nano-fluids in the temperature range of 25 to 50oC and solid volume fractions ranging from 0 to 0.6%. He reported a thermal conductivity enhancement with growing temperature and solid volume fraction. The maximum enhancement of thermal conductivity ratio was 21.3% in solid volume fraction of 0.6% and temperature of 25°C. Harandi et al. [117] studied the thermal conductivity of MWCNTs-Fe3O4/EG hybrid nano-fluid in the temperature range of 25-50 oC and the solid volume fractions up to 2.3%. They showed that in the solid volume fraction of 2.3% and a temperature of 50°C, the thermal conductivity enhanced by about 30%. They also found that at greater temperatures the influence of the solid volume fraction on the thermal conductivity was upper than the lesser temperatures. Shamaeil et al. [118] studied the thermal conductivity of DWCNTs/EG nano-fluid at a temperature range of 27-50oC. They considered solid volume fractions of 0.02, 0.05, 0.075, 0.1, 0.25 and 0.6%. Their results showed that the thermal conductivity enhanced with growing temperature and solid volume fraction of nano-particles. Soltanimehr and Afrand [119] examined the thermal conductivity a mixture of water and EG (40:60) containing of MWCNTs at temperature range of 25-50°C. They increased the solid volume fractions up to 1% and observed that the thermal conductivity augmented with enhancing temperature and solid volume fraction. The maximum enhancement was 34.7% at a temperature of 50oC and a solid volume fraction of 1%. Their results also revealed that in greater solid volume fractions, the temperature effect on the thermal conductivity ratio is more evident. Toghraie et al. [120] examined the hybrid the thermal conductivity of EG containing hybrid nano-additives of ZnO-TiO2 at a temperature interval of 25, 30, 35, 40, 45 and 50 oC and solid volume fraction up to 3.5%. Their results showed that by growing the temperature and the nano-particles volume fraction, the thermal conductivity also increases. Vafaei et al. [121] examined the effect of MgO-MWCNTs hybrid nano-additives on the thermal conductivity of EG with solid volume fractions of 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.4 and 0.6% using artificial neural network and experimental data. Zeng and Xuan [122] reported 7% enhancement of the water thermal conductivity by adding CNT-SiO2/Ag nanoadditives. Hamid et al. [123] considered the thermal conductivity of TiO2/SiO2 hybrid nanoparticles in a 40:60 EG/water base-fluid in a 1 vol.%. They reported that the thermal conductivity enhanced by 16 Vol%. Asadi et al. [26] studied the Al2O3 / MWCNTS nano-fluids at a temperature of 50 ° C and a volumetric volume of 1.5, and observed that this increased by 25%. Isfahani et al. [124] examined the water thermal conductivity containing ZnO/Ag hybrid nano-additives at different temperatures and solid volume fraction. They observed that the Brownian coefficient
11
augmented with growing Brown's motion. Esfe et al. [125] inspected the thermal conductivity of SWCNTs/EG nano-fluid. They reported that the thermal conductivity enhanced by 45% at 50°C and 7.5 vol%. Ahangarpour and Farbod [126] added CNTS nano-particles to the base-fluid EG increases the thermal conductivity of 50%. Vinodha et al. [127] studied the nano-fluids of graphene oxide and Fe3O4 and found that in a solid volume fraction 0.33%, the thermal conductivity augmented by 11%. Nadooshan et al. [7] investigated the Fe304-MWCNTs/EG nano-fluids. Esfe et al. [128] studied the thermal conductivity of DWCNTs-SiO2 / EG and showed that by addition of nano-particles to the base-fluid, the thermal conductivity increased by 38% pure fluid. DWCNTSSiO2 / EG nano-fluids by Esfe and Esfandeh [129] DWCNTS-zro2 / oil by Esfe et al. [130], DWCNTS-TiO2 / oil by Esfe et al. [131] DWCNTS-CuO / EG by Esfe et al. [132] It was found that the addition of these nano-particles increases the conduction .Many researchers have also seen an increase in the thermal conductivity by adding nano-particles by adding multi-wall nanotubes to different fluids [133-136]. Many researchers investigated the hybrid nano-fluids and found that these nano-particles have a high thermal conductivity [137-140], while using the hybrid nanoparticles structure reduces the viscosity of some nano-fluids. In this regard, Ranjbarzadeh et al., in an experimental study showed that the nano-fluids viscosity of the combined water / oxidegraphene-silica oxide ratio has decreased compared to the graphene water nano-fluids. The results of this study can show one positive effect of the combination of nano-fluids [141].

According to Table (1), it is observed that the base nano-particles and base-fluids have a different conduction. Due to the application of the nano fluid, where it is used, its base-fluid is also selected and each fluid has its own application. But what kind of nano-particles is used to choose from, such as the physical properties of the nano-particles, the nano-fluids stability created by the nanoparticles, the nanosized heat conduction, the nano-fluids viscosity, and so on. Among nano-particles used in nano-fluids, carbon nanotubes have a very high thermal conductivity. The most important part in the investigation of the thermal conductivity of nano-particles is to find the effective parameters on this. In this section, the effective parameters on the thermal conductivity of nanoparticles and their effect on nano-fluids are investigated.
5.1.Effect of volume fraction of nano-particles
According to a previous study [11], the thermal conductivity intensifies by adding nano-particles. But the important point is that due to the high price of nano-particles, the increase in this coefficient occurs by adding how much nano-particles to the base-fluid. Therefore, it can be said that the most effective parameter on the thermal conductivity is the volume concentration of nano-particles, which has been studied in all investigations. Masuda et al. [50] were the first researchers to measure nano-fluids conductivity. They employed a two-stage method to produce nano-particles and tested different nano-particles, such as alumina particles, silicon dioxide and titanium dioxide in water. Their results indicated a 32.4% improvement in thermal conductivity with a 4.3% volume fraction of alumina nano-fluid at 31.8 ° C. The thermal conductivity increased linearly with increasing volume fraction. Lee et al. [156] tested nano particles of alumina and copper oxide produced by gas condensation in water and ethylene glycol. The experiment was carried out at room temperature, and the results, like the results of Masuda et al., Showed an increase in the thermal conductivity of the volume fraction linearly. The highest observed improvement was 20%, which was obtained in 4% nano-particles of ethylene glycol-copper oxide. Wang et al. [63] also experimented with the similar work of nano-fluids containing nano particles of alumina and copper oxide. For nanoalumina, water absorption increased by 40% in a volume fraction of 8%. For all nano-fluids with base-fluid and ethylene glycol, the relationship between thermal conductivity and linear fraction was found, and lines representing this relationship were consistent. Lee et al. [157] investigated the thermal conductivity of copper oxide and ethylene glycol and found that in a 4% solid volume fraction age, this coefficient increased by 20%. Shin and Lee [158] saw an increase of 13% in the polycyclic polyoxymethylene conductivity in silicon oil in solid volume fraction were 10%. They changed the solid volume fraction of nano-particles from 0.1% to 3%, and they found that with increasing temperature and solid volume fractions of nano-particles, the thermal conductivity increased. The maximum increase of this coefficient by 90% predicted that a 3% vol% and a temperature of 55 ° C would occur.
5.2.Effect of changing the size of nano-particles
In this section, the effect of nano-particles size on the heat transfer coefficient is investigated. From the theoretical point of view, it seems that by reducing the size of nano-particles, the ratio of the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids to the base-fluid should be increased. The effect of the nano-particles size on the thermal conductivity of the transient studies has been carried out, and various results have also been reported. In some studies, it has been shown that increasing the size of nano-particles increases the thermal conductivity, while in other studies it has been shown that by decreasing this particle size, the thermal conductivity increases. Among studies such as [179,180] also show variable results and showed a different behavior with increasing particle size of nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 5.2.1. Effect of increasing the size of nano-particles
sections.text: Sun et al. [181] examined the SiC-water nano-particles conductivity with nano-particles size (10- 20-40-60) nm. They understood that with growing the size of nano-particles, the thermal conductivity also augmented. the thermal conductivity of the alumina conductivity was studied in different sizes of nano-particles and it was found that increasing the nano-particles size also increased the thermal conductivity [82,183]. Shima and Philip [184] investigated the thermal conductivity of Fe3O4-kerosene in sizes of 2.8, 3.6, 6.1, 8.2 and 9.5 nm and observed that the thermal conductivity also increases with growing nano-particles size. Timofeeva et al. [185] studied the thermal conductivity SiC-water in 4 several sizes of nano-particles and observed that growing the size of nano-particles also increased the thermal conductivity.

sections.heading: 5.2.2. Effect of decreasing the size of nano-particles
sections.text:
Esfe et al. [169] investigated the thermal conductivity of Fe-water nano-particles in different sizes of nano-particles, and found that the thermal conductivity increased with decreasing nano-particles size. Patel et al. [186] examined the thermal conductivity of aluminum nano-particles in the fluid
15
base of water and fluid in the base of ethylene glycol in the size of nano-particles (10-45-150). They found that by reducing the size of the nano-particles, the thermal conductivity increased. This increase is higher in the ethylene glycol base-fluid chopkar et al. [187] studied the Al2Cu-water nano-fluids thermal conductivity. The size of the nano-particles they tested included (25-20-35-83) nm. They found that by reducing the size of the nano-particles, the thermal conductivity increases. In the fluid base of the water, in most cases, the thermal conductivity is 1.9 times, and in equilibrium of ethylene glycol fluid 1.8 equals. He et al. [188] examined the thermal conductivity of TiO2-water in different sizes of nano-particles and observed that with a reduction in the size of the nano-particles, conductivity increases. Liu et al. [40] studied the nano-fluids conductivity of copper in two solid volume fractions of 0.1 and 0.2% solid volume fraction and different sizes of nanoparticles. They found that by reducing the size of the nano-particles, the thermal conductivity amplified significantly. Patel et al. [189] considered the gold nano-particles in base water and toluene in various solid volume fraction and temperatures. They found that reducing the size of gold nano-particles increases the thermal conductivity. Paul et al. [190] examined the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids water at room temperature and solid volume fractions (0.00006- 0.00026). They investigated the thermal conductivity of gold in two sizes of 21 and 75 nm and observed that by decreasing the size of nano-particles, the thermal conductivity rises. Some researchers [191-194] investigated the thermal conductivity of alumina nanofluid containing different sizes nano-particles. They understood that by reducing the size of the nano-particles, the thermal conductivity augmented. In Fig. 3, the ratio of the nano-fluids conductivity of the alumina has been determined at two temperatures and different mass ratios of the nano-particles. In this figure, the effect of the particle size is paid. As seen in the figure, at 50 ° C with increasing diameter of the nano-particles, we decrease the ratio of the thermal conductivity, but at the temperature of 10 o C, this ratio increases with increasing diameter of the nano-particles. Therefore, it cannot be conclusively expressed about the effect of the size of nano-particles on the theoretical thermal conductivity.

5.3.Effect of changing the temperature
According to researches on the effect of temperature on the thermal conductivity, this parameter also has a different effect on the thermal conductivity. In some papers, this parameter increases the thermal conductivity and in others it decreases this coefficient. Moreover, in some studies, the behavior of variations in the thermal conductivity varies with the temperature variation and cannot be a good result [162,195].

sections.heading: 5.3.1. Effect of increasing the temperature
sections.text:
Das et al. [196] compared the thermal conductivity of the alumina nano-fluids at two temperatures of 21 ° C and 50 ° C. They showed that the thermal conductivity improved with enhancing temperature. Timofeeva et al. [197] also examined the thermal conductivity of the alumina in two temperatures of 20 ° C and 60 ° C and achieved similar results. Abareshi et al. [198] also considered the temperature effect on the thermal conductivity of the alumina nano-fluid. they understood that the thermal conductivity augmented as the temperature increased. Xuan et al. [199] presented a new method to simulate the accumulating process in nano-fluids using the Brownian motion theory. Li and Peterson et al. [64] and Das et al. [200] considered the thermal conductivity of two nano particles of oxide and alumina in a water-base-fluid. They found that for both nano-fluids, the thermal conductivity rises with growing temperature. Qiao [201] evaluated the thermal conductivity of silver nano-particles in two water-base and ethylene glycol fluid at 20 and 60 ° C, and a volume fraction of 0.121% and a nano-particles size of 60 nm. He observed that the thermal conductivity ratio augmented with a temperature increase of about 0.7 murshed et al. [202] studied the thermal conductivity of titania in water at temperatures of 15 and 35oC, and observed that the thermal conductivity enhanced as the temperature increased. Huminic et al. [203] studied the FeC / Water thermal conductivity in 1% vol% and temperatures of 15 ° C and 70 ° C and found similar results. Patel et al. [186] investigated the thermal coefficient of different nano-particles with temperature variation. They were aluminum nano-fluids with a mixture of water and ethylene glycol, an aluminum alloy with ethylene glycol, copper with water and copper with it in a volume fraction of 1%. All the biosensors were investigated at temperatures of 20, 30, 40 and 50oC, and in all cases, the thermal conductivity enhanced with augmenting temperature. Sundar et al. [204] determined the thermal conductivity of ND-Ni nano-particles load in water fluid and again in ethylene glycol fluid. In both, the thermal conductivity enhanced with augmenting temperature. Jiang et al. [170] examined the thermal conductivity of Cu / N-tetradecane at two temperatures of 33 and 173 and found that nano-fluids at higher temperature had a much higher conductivity than that of lower temperatures. Esfe et al. [205] examined the thermal conductivity of the combination of Cu and TiO2 nano-particles in a mixture of water and EG. They performed the experiments on prepared nano-fluids at a temperature range of 30 to 60oC and observed that the thermal conductivity enhanced as temperature increased. Glory et al. [72] studied the thermal conductivity of MWCNT / Water in temperatures of 15 and 75. It was detected that the thermal conductivity augmented with enhancing temperature. Nasiri et al. [134] studied the MWCNTs/water nano-fluid thermal conductivity in a temperature range of 10-50oC at 5 different temperatures, and observed that the thermal conductivity augmented with intensification of temperature. Amrollahi et al. [206] examined the SWCNTs/water nano-fluids conductivity and recorded an increasing trend of
18
conductivity or temperature. Karimipour et al. [207] investigated the CuO/liquid paraffin nanofluids conductivity. They were found that the thermal conductivity increased with growing temperature and solid volume fraction of nano-particles. Ding et al. [112] examined the thermal conductivity of MWCNT / Water and the control increase of the thermal conductivity was increased by temperature. Wan et al. [208] investigated the polyaniline nano-fluids conductivity at three different temperatures and observed that the thermal conductivity augmented as the temperature increased. Fig. 4 shows the variations in the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids at different temperatures.

sections.heading: 5.3.2. Effect of decreasing the temperature
sections.text:
Masuda et al. [50] investigated the thermal conductivity of salicylic oxide and water oxide with nano-particles at temperatures of 31.85-46.85-66.85 ° C. They found that the thermal conductivity
19
decreases with increasing temperature. Gao et al. [214] examined the thermal conductivity of Al2O3/HD and found that by growing the temperature from 5 to 52 oC, the thermal conductivity decreases. Branson et al. [215] studied ND / MO thermal conductivity and found that by growing the temperature from 60 to 100°C, the thermal conductivity reduced by 0.02%. Castro et al. [216] examined the thermal conductivity of MWCNTs/Ionic water. Their findings showed that by increasing the temperature, the thermal conductivity decreased by 1%.
5.4.Investigating the effect of Particle shapes and Aspect Ratio
A large number of studies have shown that increasing the nano-particles aspect ratio also increases the thermal conductivity [163, 217, and 218]. Murshed et al. [45]. Studied the thermal conductivity of TiO2 / Water nano-fluid in two aspect ratios. They found that, as the ratio increases, the thermal conductivity increases. Glory et al. [72] investigated the nano-fluids conductivity MWCNTs / water in different lengths in a 1% volume fraction. They found that increasing the nano-particles length and increasing the aspect ratio increased the thermal conductivity. This increase in length (0.5- 1.1.7-5) µm is 48% -18-38%. Farbod et al. [219] examined the thermal conductivity of Cu / Engine oil (SAE20W50) in a 0.28 solid volume fraction. They found that Nanorod's conductivity is greater than that of nano rhombic, and these two are more than the sphere. Assael et al. [111] compared the thermal conductivity of DWCNTs/water and MWCNTs/water in a 1% volume fraction. They observed that the thermal conductivity in the first case was 3% and in the second case it increased by 35%. Xie et al. [220] examined the thermal conductivity of silicon carbide/water nano-fluids in a solid volume fraction age of 4% and in spherical and cylindrical quantities. In spherical mode, the thermal conductivity is increased by 10% and in cylindrical mode by 20%. Timofeeva et al. [221] examined the thermal conductivity of the alumina nano-particles in the base-fluid, of water and ethylene glycol in a 7% volume. They drew on the effect of different forms of nano-particles on the thermal conductivity; and found that thermal conductivity of different forms of nano-particles increased. Nasiri et al. [134] investigated the CNT / water nano-fluid thermal conductivity in 0.25% by weight. They found that the thermal conductivity of various forms, including SWNT-SWNTFWNT-MWNT, increased by 13-16-21%, respectively. In Fig. 5, the ratio of the thermal conductivity of CNT-R113 nano-particles has been estimated with different sizes in different percentages of solid volume fraction. It is observed that by increasing the aspect ratio, the ratio of the thermal conductivity increases, which is higher in the smaller particle diameter. In Fig. 6, the thermal conductivity of SiC / water nano-fluids is given for two types of particle shape in different solid volume fraction ages. SiC-26 forms a spherical particle with a diameter of 26 nanometers, and
20
in SiC-600 particles are nanotubes and their lengths are 600 nm. It is detected that the ratio of the thermal conductivity is higher for nanotube shape.

5.5.Examination of Nano-inclusions
In general, by increasing the thermal conductivity of nano-particles in suspension, the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids increases. [186, 222] Hwang et al. [223] studied the thermal conductivity of nano-SiO2 and MWCNT and CuO in flowing water base in the volume fraction of 1 percent compared. The thermal conductivity of nano-particles is considered to be 1.4-6600 and 385 W/m.K respectively. They found that the thermal conductivity increased by 3-11-5%, respectively. Zhu et al. [165] studied the thermal conductivity of nano- Al2O3, TiO2 and Fe3O4 in flowing water base in the volume fraction of 4 percent compared. The nano-particles were considered to be 9-15- 35w / (m.K), respectively. They found that the thermal conductivity increased by 30-30-38%, respectively. Yoo et al. [78] compared the thermal conductivity of Al2O3, TiO2 particles in a waterbased base-fluid in a 1% volume fraction, and found that by adding this nano-particles, the thermal conductivity Chopkar et al. [224] examined the thermal conductivity of Ag2Al/water, Al2Cu/Water nano-particles in a 1.8% solid volume fraction, respectively. The results show them by 140 per cent and 120 per cent of the thermal conductivity is augmented. Sinha et al. Angayarkanni & Philip [167] added alumina, silica and titania nano-particles to the base-fluid. They compared their nano-fluids thermal conductivity. The thermal conductivity of nano-particles was considered to be 35, 1.4 and 15 W/m.K, respectively. Shima and Philip [226] investigated the role of dispersed nano-material thermal conductivity on the rheological and thermal properties of nano-fluids, stabilized with a mono-layer of surfactant. They used Fe3O4 and Ag nanoparticles. Balla et al. [227] studied thermal conductivity of nano copper and nano zinc in a 50- nanometer particle size in water fluid for both of them. They are mixing ratio of 1 to 3 of copper and zinc nano-particles and measured the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids. They found that increasing the thermal conductivity of nano particles cause thermal conductivity of nano-fluids is increased also most increase thermal conductivity appeared on the temperature 20 ° C and 1 vol%.
5.6.Impact of Additives
In general, the addition of additives increases the nano-fluids stability and prevents the accumulation of nano-particles. Most articles also show that adding additives increases the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids. Eastman et al. [228] studied the EG based Cu guiding coefficient by adding thioglycolic acid as a stabilizer. They reported that with the presence of nano-particles alone, the thermal conductivity augmented by 10%, and when thioglycolic acid was added to the suspension, the thermal conductivity was increased by 40%. Although only thioglycolic acid was present in the solution (without nano-particles) In the conduction curve, wang et al. [222] did not investigate the copper or alumina nano-fluids in the water base-fluid and found that using a suitable concentration of SDBS, nano-fluids thermal conductivity can be increased. Phuoc et al. [ 229] by studying the CNT / Water nanofiller found that by adding Chitosan in a percentage of the mass, the nano-fluids thermal conductivity could be increased by 4.3% He examined xia et al. [193] to study the nano-fluids of alumina in a 0.5% vol volume. They once examined the thermal conductivity factor by adding SDS and adding PVA to the nano-fluids once again. They found that by adding a good concentration of these additives, the heat conductivity could be increased to slightly higher solid volume fraction. The nano-fluids of alumina in a solid volume fraction of 4% was studied by Angayarkanni & Philip [230]. They reported that by adding NP9 and SDS additives the thermal conductivity augmented by 18 and 13 percent, respectively. They also investigated the thermal conductivity of silicon oxide and water oxide by adding NP9 and CTAB in the same solid volume fractions, and found that the thermal conductivity increased by 9 and 10%. Zhu et al. [56] found that by adding an optimal concentration of SDBS, the coefficient Agarwal et al. [231] examined the
22
nano-fluids of MWCNT / PAO nano-fluids with polyisobutylene succinimide (PIBSI) as the dispersant and found that the percentage of conductivity was lower in PIBSI with a 3% mass percentage. Moreover, for EG and water-based CNT nano-fluids by adding SDS, there is no particular change in the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids [232,233].
5.7.Study the effect of base-fluid
The thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids is also dependent on the thermal conductivity of the base-fluid, but due to the complexity of the heat transfer mechanism in the nano-particles and the presence of parameters such as Brownian motion, clustering, nanolayers, etc., we cannot easily We cannot easily comment on the enhancement of thermal conductivity. The base-fluid also increases the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids [103]. Many articles such as [163, 223, 234-236] have investigated the increase in the thermal conductivity. Wang et al. [63] examined the thermal conductivity of alumina and copper oxide nano-particles in various base-fluids of water, EG, vacuum pump oil, and EO. They found that the highest thermal conductivity for the base-fluid was water, EG, EO, and vacuum pump oil, respectively. It is also the highest thermal coefficient ratio for EG, water, EO and pump oil, respectively. Xie et al. [237] studied the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids containing MWCNT nano-particles in the three basic fluids, EG and decene. They found that by adding carbon nanotubes, the thermal conductivity increased; and by increasing the base-fluid it decreased. Ruan and Jacobi [238] investigated the thermal conductivity of the MWCNT atoms in base water and EG fluids in 0.24% vol% and found that for both base-fluid the thermal conductivity increased by 9%. Liu et al. [136] studied the thermal conductivity of MWCNT in EG and synthetic motor oil. They found that in an EG-based nano-fluid in the solid volume fraction of 2%, thermal conductivity augmented by about 30%, and in an EO-based nano-fluids with a 1% vol increase, thermal conductivity augmented by 12.4%. Agarwal et al. [239] studied the thermal conductivity of Al2O3 in DW and EG. They found that the change in the thermal conductivity of water-based nano-fluids often depends intensely on the solid volume fraction of nano-particles and temperature, while in an EG-based nano-fluids by volume it is more dependent on the temperature and rises with growing the solid volume fraction age relative to the temperature. However, water-based nano-fluids have a more effective role in heat transfer where the temperature is more prominent. While the EG-based nano-fluids is more appropriate in places where the volume is more prominent. Li et al. [240] examined the thermal conductivity of the nano-particles in the two basic fluids of water and EG and found that the thermal conductivity of the base-fluid decreases. In Fig. 7, the thermal conductivity of copper oxide and alumina nano-particles in different base percentages is given in different percentages of solid volume fraction. According to
23
the figure, with increasing the thermal conductivity of the base-fluid, the thermal conductivity of the nano-fluids is also increased.
5.8.Effect of pH
Despite the fact that the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids depends on their pH, the number of articles in this field is low. When oxides add metals to water, they form in the hydrogen radicals OH ^ + OH ^ +. Now, depending on the type of nano-particles in the water and the reactions formed between the nano-particles and the water, acidic nano-fluids are played or played. If the nanoparticles has a positive charge load, H2 + H2 + will be acidic nano-fluids, and if the nano-particles has a negative charge load of OH ^ + OH ^ +, the nano-fluids is played. At a pH value, the mixture of nano-particles and water reaches a point where the number of ions + ve and ions -ve is equal. This state of affinity is isoelectric point. The isoelectric point depends on the type of metal oxide
24
nano-particles. If the nano-fluids PH is close to this point, nano-particles may stick together and this affects the thermal conductivity. Xie et al. [236] discovered the effect of pH on the thermal conductivity of the alumina nano-fluids in the base water and EG fluids. They found that by increasing the difference between the nano-fluids pH and the isoelectric point, the thermal conductivity increased. Habibzade et al. [244] reported that by growing the pH For SnO2 nanoparticles, the thermal conductivity also intensifies. They observed that at pH = 8 times the surface was higher and different behavior was observed from the nano-particles, but eventually this behavior increased the thermal conductivity. Li et al. [245] observed that by diverging the pH from the isoelectric point of loading Surface is increased [45, 188] to investigate the effect of pH on the TiO2 conductivity. He et al. [188] considered the particle size 20 nm and investigated the thermal conductivity. PH = 11 and murshed et al. [45] considered the particle size of 15 nm and examined the thermal conductivity at pH = 2-8. Wang et al. [222] studied the thermal conductivity of copper/water and alumina nano-particles. They observed that the thermal conductivity depends on pH. They also reported that the ratio of thermal conductivity augmented with growing pH at low pH (Al2O3 less than 7.5 and copper less than 9). However, at higher pH (alumina greater than 8 and more than 9.5), the ratio of thermal conductivity decreased with increasing pH. Zhu et al. [56] examined the thermal conductivity of alumina and found that this coefficient strongly depends on pH and, with increasing pH, the thermal conductivity increases from 3 to 8-9. Another work, such as [246,247], is also about the effect of pH on the thermal conductivity, which has the same results with other studies. Finally, according to the above-mentioned studies, the thermal conductivity is highly dependent on pH, and this parameter should be considered more. Lee et al. [248] The thermal conductivity of copper oxide nano-fluids in the room at pH 3 and 6 They found that increasing the pH would reduce the conduction factor. In Fig. 8, the ratio of thermal conductivity of nano-liquids to aluminum and copper is shown for various pH values. As in the figure, the thermal conductivity in the playing area is less than that of the acid. The highest ratio of heat thermal conductivity is in the range of pH 8-9.

sections.heading: 6. Effect of nano-particles on human body
sections.text:
Due to the industrialization of nano-particles and their application in various devices, human communication with these devices has increased. Hence, different researchers have been investigating the effect of nano-particles on human health. In Fig. 9, some parts of the body affected by the nano-particles and related diseases are shown.
33
Fig. 9. Effect of different nano-particles on various parts of the body. [38, 39]
A study of neurobehavioral tests on labors at Nano-particles production plants demonstrated that their backward memory has been decreased due to high concentration of Nano-particles and continuous contact with them [314,315]. The degree of toxicity of nano-particles depends on various parameters. Evaluation of these parameters has been one of the major issues for researchers. They found that the toxicity of Nanoparticles is influenced by properties including size [316], charge, shape, surface chemistry/coating [317], production of reactive oxygen species [318] and flexibility [319, 320]. In other studies, the researchers investigated the effect of nano-particles on human health. They found that Nano-particles such as iron (5nm) [321], TiO2 [322], quantom dots [323], Ag Nanoparticles (5nm) [324] were able to cross the skin. These substances increase the probability of skin aging by producing reactive oxygen species [325]. Fig. 10 shows a schematic of part of the skin where the nano-particles pass through and enter the bloodstream due to their small size.
34
In two separate studies [326,327], the researchers investigated the influence of penetration of nanoparticles into the skin and their effects on the body. Their results demonstrated that the penetration of Nano-particles can cause systemic exposure and cause lesions in the body. Biskos et al. [328] investigated the effect of nano-particles size and their deposition location. They found that most of the deposition of airborne Nano-particles is in the range of 5–50nm within alveoli. The deposition in these areas creates maximum risk of toxicity. In Fig. 11, alveoli is shown. Accumulation of nano-particles in the inhalation causes less oxygen to enter the bloodstream
35
Fig. 11. Schematic of the lung and the alveoli area where the nano-particles are deposited [328, 39]
Also, the researchers found that due to the large surface area of the lungs and the small size of airborn Nano-particles, they can cross the thin blood air barriers and enter the systemic bloodstream, which can easily reach all organs of the body [329,330]. Fig. 12 illustrates how oxygen is absorbed in the alveoli. Nano-particles pass through this area, causing the nano-particles to enter the bloodstream and move to different parts of the body
36
Another study revealed that Ag Nano-particles can cause bile-duct hyperplasia, necrosis, fibrosis, and creation of pigmentation in the rat [331]. The results of two other articles also demonstrated that TiO2Nano-particles can cause hepatic injury, thrombosis, tachycardia, and systolic hypertension [332, 333]. Fig. 13 presents a sample of a blood clot that may be due to the accumulation of nano-particles in the vein.
Lucchini et al. [334] investigated the effect of nano-particles on children. They found that motor, cognitive, and behavioral changes have been observed in children exposed to particulate atal Nanoparticles. Holt et al. [335] studied the effect of nano-particles on infants. Their results showed that nanoparticles act as an allergen during infancy. These allergens enter into the body and activate the immune system to create allergic inflammation in later stages of their life.
37
Araujo et al. [336] investigated the effect of nano-particles on epidemiological diseases. They found that detrimental cardiovascular consequence diseases have been reported due to the exposure to Nano-particles. Lu et al. [337] studied the effect of different nano-particles on human experimentally. In vitro and in vivo studies showed that metallic Nano-particles, carbon-based Nano-particles, and dendrimers have the potential to cause adverse effects such as reproductive failure, metabolic syndrome, and cancer. In addition, some studies have shown that some Nano-particles can have adverse effects on human reproductive structure by making changes in testicular and ovarian structure and function [338, 339].

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: This article focuses on experimental studies performed on measurement of nano-fluid thermal conductivity and evaluates the influence of effective parameters on nano-fluid thermal conductivity including volume fraction and size of nano-particles, temperature, aspect ratio, base-fluid, pH, nano inclusions, and additives. Also, due to the importance of hybrid nano-fluids, a separate section related to the articles published in this field is provided. Since the researchers have direct contact to the nano-particles to measure their properties, a part of the paper reviews the effect of nanoparticles on humans and the environment. The results demonstrated that the parameters mentioned above have a direct effect on thermal conductivity. Also, according to the results of some papers, hybrid nano-fluids have better thermal properties than mono nano-fluids. Based on the investigations, human exposure to nano-particles can have many adverse effects on various parts of the body include the skin, lungs, liver, gastrointestinal system, brain, etc. It reveals that the researchers in contact with nanomaterials should avoid to direct contact with nanomaterials. The nano-particles also have destructive effects on the soil and water. If they enter the environment, animals in contact with these nano-particles have problems.

sections.heading: 8. Challenge and suggestion for future work
sections.text:
In general, the researchers in measuring the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids have some challenges as follows:
• Although there are many papers on nano-fluid measurement, there is not similar data.
Different results have been reported related to thermal conductivity under the same conditions.
38
• Most of the papers have focused on thermal conductivity of metal and metal oxides nano-
fluids. The researchers have not considered new nanomaterials.
• Due to the industrialization of nanotechnology, it is necessary to find methods to lessen
human and environmental contact with nano-particles.
Moreover, due to the existing challenges, related suggestions are also provided:
Standardize the time interval for measuring the thermal conductivity of nano-fluids in which researchers report the effect of changing one parameter to investigate its effect. This interval should also include the steps of nano-fluid preparation and its homogenization. Using new nano-particles to prepare nano-fluids, especially those that are eco-friendly or those made from the environment. Reduction of human exposure to nano-particles in the laboratory using a device instead of human in the preparation and measurement of nano-fluid properties.

metadata.abstractText: Nano-fluids are produced by combining one or more nano-particles in a base-fluid. Nano-fluids, especially hybrid nano-fluids, have better thermal conductivitys than simple liquids. The results of various articles demonstrated that various parameters such as nano-particles size, their volume fraction, temperature, aspect ratio, base-fluid, nano inclusions, additive, and pH affect nano-fluid thermal conductivity. In this paper, the effect of these parameters is reviewed by considering experimental works performed on thermal conductivity. Since thermal conductivity is measured by researchers experimentally, it is also important for researchers to understand the effect of nanoparticles on humans and the environment. Thus, in this article, published articles in this field are reviewed and the effect of nano-particles on human and environment are investigated. The results of these articles indicated that nano-particles can endanger human health and can have irreversible effects on human health. The nano-particles also have a devastating effect on the environment and can affect the water, soil, and animals.
